{"step_by_step_thinking": "Based on the patient's history and desire to delay pregnancy, the most appropriate next step in management would be to administer ulipristal acetate. Ulipristal acetate is a selective progesterone receptor modulator that can be used as emergency contraception up to 120 hours (5 days) after unprotected intercourse. It is more effective than levonorgestrel, another commonly used emergency contraceptive, especially when taken closer to the time of intercourse. Copper-containing intra-uterine device (Choice A) can also be used as emergency contraception, but it requires a visit to a healthcare provider for insertion. Mifepristone (Choice B) is used for medical abortion, not emergency contraception. Depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (Choice D) is a long-acting contraceptive method that is not appropriate for emergency contraception.", "answer_choice": "C"}
